title: New York’s midnight ritual
text:
Email a friend 
IT’S one of the world’s most visited tourist attractions, but only a small few stick around to see it transform every night. 
330,000 each day pour into Times Square in New York. They’re there to take in the spectacle of the huge billboards, perhaps visit a Broadway show, or to indulge in kitschy tourist traps. 
But only a few of these know to stick around to midnight as the busy intersection transforms into something spectacular. 
For three-minutes in the lead up to midnight, a digital “countdown” marks the beginning of not just a new day, but an idea that’s changed the way we look at modern art. 
Every night at 11:57pm, Times Square transforms into a digital art gallery, using its billboards as a canvas to display cutting-edge digital images. They call it Midnight Moment. And it’s really, freaking, cool. 
“[We] wanted to be able to create a sense of excitement every night of the year,” Sherry Dobbin, Director of Times Square, told news.com.au. 
“I never get tired or jaded about watching the expression of wonder, when people realise what is happening around them. They have the same expression of joy as though watching a meteor shower. 
“Where else can one see this? Times Square is an iconic public place shaped like an electronic canyon.” 
Every month a new artist is commissioned to have their artwork in lights, and so far, we’ve seen the likes of Andy Warhol, Yoko Ono and Bjork take centre stage. 
Here’s a glimpse of what to expect. 'The Conductor: Fortuna Imperatrix Mundi' by Rashaad Newsome Midnight Moment August 2015: OSGEMEOS 'Parallel Connection' Midnight Moment July 2015: Eric Dyer 'Copenhagen Cycles Journey'
